meta.title: Code Blue
meta.notes: Canon layout: long narrative + separator + CHOICES block with pill labels + long descriptions. ASCII-only.

S01.text:
Your first real shift hits you in layers: antiseptic, burnt coffee, sweat under disposable gowns. The ER is not chaos the way movies sell it. It is controlled violence. Alarms chirp in patterns you do not recognize yet. Wheels squeal. Voices overlap. Everyone moves like the building itself is pushing them forward.

Dr. Adrian Cole. Intern. The title feels flimsy compared to the weight of the room. You adjust your badge as if tightening it will tighten you.

A senior resident cuts through the bay like a blade. She does not waste words. Orders land and people obey. She clocks you once, the way a predator clocks distance, then keeps moving.

An ER nurse threads between bodies and equipment without slowing down. She catches a falling chart with her foot and never breaks eye contact with the patient she is calming. When she hands you gloves, her fingers linger just long enough to be intentional. Her expression says: do not embarrass yourself.

Down the hall, another intern laughs too loudly. Too comfortable. Too quick to treat the shift like a stage. He throws a look your way like you are either competition or entertainment.

No one welcomes you. No one should.

You have a choice: be seen, be useful, or be safe. None of those are free.

----------------
CHOICES
1) SHADOW RESIDENT - Stay tight to the senior resident and learn how power moves in this place. You will earn respect if you keep up, but you will also get blamed if you slow her down.
2) HELP NURSE - Jump in beside the ER nurse and let her put you to work. You will learn the real rhythm of the room fast, but she will notice every weakness and every excuse.
3) MATCH INTERN - Keep pace with the other intern and refuse to be outshined on day one. You may gain social footing, but rivalry here turns personal quickly.
4) STICK TO PROTOCOL - Start with charts, procedures, and safe tasks. You protect your future, but you risk becoming invisible at exactly the wrong moment.

S02.text:
You fall in behind the senior resident and immediately regret how long your legs feel. She moves like every hallway belongs to her.

She does not introduce herself. She does not explain. She hands you a chart mid-stride and keeps talking to a respiratory therapist without slowing down.

You skim while walking. Vitals. History. Allergies. A note from the attending that reads like a warning. The resident glances back once, not at the paper, at you.

You keeping up?

It is not unkind. It is a filter.

A patient groans behind the curtain. The resident pushes it aside, steps in, and takes control in three sentences. When she looks at you again, her face is calm but her eyes are sharp.

You realize something: she does not care if you like her. She cares if you are useful.

And still, there is an edge to her attention that is not purely clinical.

----------------
CHOICES
1) KEEP PACE - You answer fast, move fast, and accept that you may be wrong for a second as long as you correct fast. It makes you look fearless, and it might get someone hurt.
2) ASK CLARITY - You slow just enough to confirm your reasoning. You protect the patient and your credibility, but you risk looking soft under pressure.
3) TAKE INITIATIVE - You propose the next step before she asks. If you are right, you earn her respect. If you are wrong, you earn her memory.
4) STAY QUIET - You watch and absorb without pushing. You avoid mistakes in public, but you also give up the chance to stand out.

S03.text:
You choose the nurse.

She does not slow down to teach. She teaches by throwing you into the current and seeing whether you drown.

Intern, she says, already moving. Gloves. Gauze. IV kit. If you faint, aim away from the sterile field.

You do not know if she is joking. The way she says it makes everyone nearby smile like this is a ritual.

A patient starts yelling. The nurse leans in, voice low, and the shouting drops to a ragged whisper. She is good at this. Not just medicine. People.

You help restrain, clean, steady. Then you notice a charting shortcut on the computer: a time stamp that is not exact, a box checked because it will be checked later. Not dangerous, but not clean.

Your eyes flick to her. Her eyes flick to you.

She knows you saw it. The question is what you do with that knowledge.

----------------
CHOICES
1) COVER FOR HER - You quietly fix the entry later without making it a scene. No one gets hurt, but she learns you will bend rules to protect her, and that has a price.
2) SAY SOMETHING - You flag it now, in the moment, even if it slows care. You protect the record and your ethics, but you risk her trust and her patience.
3) LET IT GO - You pretend you did not see it. You keep the peace, but you also teach yourself what you are willing to ignore.
4) ASK PRIVATELY - You pull her aside away from eyes and ask what happened. You keep her dignity intact, but you still step onto a line that she may push back against.

S04.text:
You fall in alongside the other intern and immediately feel the social physics of the place. He is already orbiting attention.

First shift? he says, grinning. Relax. They only eat the nervous ones.

He talks while walking, like the hospital is a runway. He drops a diagnosis loud enough for two nurses and an attending to hear. It is mostly right. Mostly is not comforting.

You catch the missing piece. The part that could matter. The part that could make you look smart or make you look like an enemy.

The attending looks your way, waiting to see who claims the room.

Your rival does not look worried. That worries you.

----------------
CHOICES
1) CORRECT QUIETLY - You pull him aside and fix the call without humiliating him. You protect the patient and avoid a public fight, but he may resent you anyway.
2) LET HIM RUN - You stay out of it and let the system correct him. You keep your hands clean, but you gamble with someone else's outcome.
3) OUTPERFORM HIM - You step in with the better answer in front of everyone. You gain status fast and make an enemy faster.
4) BACK HIM UP - You support his call despite doubt. If it goes well, you gain an ally. If it goes wrong, you share the fall.

S05.text:
You choose the safe route.

Charts. Protocols. Orders that do not require you to raise your voice.

No one criticizes you for it. No one praises you either.

From the edge, you see how this place really works. Who bends rules. Who enforces them. Who pretends not to notice. You see the resident's gaze track the room like a weapon. You see the nurse hide a smile when someone makes gallows humor about the coffee being stronger than the pain meds.

You also see the downside: people stop looking for you when things get loud.

Safe becomes invisible.

Invisible becomes replaceable.

----------------
CHOICES
1) STEP IN - You choose visibility now, even if you make mistakes in public. It might win respect, or it might paint a target on you.
2) KEEP OBSERVING - You keep collecting patterns and leverage. Information is power, but waiting too long can turn into cowardice.
3) CHOOSE A SIDE - You align with someone and accept their enemies with them. It builds loyalty fast and traps you faster.
4) STAY NEUTRAL - You protect your reputation on paper, but neutrality reads like weakness in a room full of predators.

S06.text:
It happens fast.

A patient decompensates. A monitor flips from annoying to screaming. Someone calls for help and suddenly there are too many hands and not enough space.

Orders overlap. Two people talk at once. A nurse swears under her breath. The resident snaps a single command and the noise reshapes around it.

You move.

Not perfectly. Not elegantly. But decisively.

You do what you know, and when you do not know, you do not freeze. You ask the right question at the right time. You catch something small before it becomes fatal.

The patient stabilizes.

Afterward, the break room feels too quiet. Adrenaline lingers in your fingers. Your shirt sticks to your back. Someone laughs, sharp and relieved.

The resident looks at you like she is recalculating. The nurse looks at you like she is deciding whether to trust you. Your rival looks at you like he just learned your name matters.

----------------
CHOICES
1) DEBRIEF OPENLY - You talk the case through with the team. It shows leadership and humility, but it exposes every mistake you made.
2) THANK SOMEONE - You single out support and build a bond. It is human, and it creates obligation you cannot take back.
3) DEFLECT CREDIT - You push attention away from yourself. It is safe politics, and it wastes momentum.
4) SAY NOTHING - You keep your face neutral and let the moment pass. It reads as control to some, and fear to others.

S07.text:
The resident pulls you into a side room and closes the door.

For a beat, neither of you speaks. The silence is intimate in a way the ER never allows.

Do not do that again, she says.

Then she pauses, eyes on you like she hates that she respects you.

Actually... do. Just warn me first.

It is the closest thing to praise she gives.

Her gaze drops to your mouth for half a second and returns to your eyes like it never happened.

The air shifts. Professional still, but thinner. A line you both see.

----------------
CHOICES
1) EARNED TRUST - You promise competence, not romance. You build something solid, and you keep the risk quiet for now.
2) STAY CLEAN - You steer away from subtext and keep it strictly professional. You protect both careers, and you may lose the spark.
3) LET IT LINGER - You do not break the tension. You let the moment breathe, inviting danger without saying a word.
4) CHANGE TOPIC - You crack a dry joke and move on. You keep control, and you may miss what she was offering.

S08.text:
The nurse finds you near the supply room, away from the main flow.

Thanks, she says. Quiet. Real.

Then, with a smirk: just do not make a habit of it.

You are not sure if she means the shortcut you noticed, the way you stepped in, or the fact that you looked for her eyes during the worst moment and found them.

She leans on the doorframe like she belongs there. Like she belongs in your space.

If you say the wrong thing, this becomes messy.

If you say nothing, it becomes a question that hangs.

----------------
CHOICES
1) PLAY IT OFF - You joke and keep it light. It preserves the moment and hides how much it hit you.
2) NAME THE RISK - You admit it could have gone wrong. Honesty in this place is rare and it can deepen trust fast.
3) ASK FOR COFFEE - You keep it casual: one coffee, one conversation. It is a doorway that can turn into a habit.
4) SET BOUNDARY - You create distance now. It protects you later, and it may sting her pride immediately.

S09.text:
Your rival laughs it off in public.

Good save, Doc, he says, too loud, too casual.

His eyes do not match the smile.

You feel it: the shift from friendly competition to personal scorekeeping. This hospital runs on reputation as much as it runs on blood.

You do not know who noticed. You only know they did.

Some people will admire you.

Some will wait for you to slip.

----------------
CHOICES
1) STAND BY IT - You do not apologize for being right. You gain backbone in the eyes of some and arrogance in the eyes of others.
2) SMOOTH IT OVER - You speak privately and cool the temperature. You keep the war cold, and you may look weaker publicly.
3) BLAME PRESSURE - You claim the moment made you act. It shields you and stains you, because excuses become a pattern.
4) ESCALATE - You bring it to a superior. That is power and it is poison, and it will follow you.

S10.text:
Your shift ends on paper. In your head, it keeps running.

You wash your hands until your skin tightens. You replay the case, the looks, the words that landed and the words you swallowed.

This hospital will remember you by the stories other people tell about you.

The resident will remember whether you are reliable.

The nurse will remember whether you are loyal.

Your rival will remember whether you are a threat.

And you will remember the first time you realized how easy it would be to become someone you did not plan to be.

Outside, the night air feels unreal.

Your phone buzzes once. Maybe it is nothing.

Maybe it is the first hook.

----------------
CHOICES
1) STAY LATE - You linger and see what happens after the official shift ends. Late hours breed secrets and invitations.
2) LEAVE NOW - You go home and reset. It protects your head and costs you whatever happens when you are not watching.
3) CHECK MESSAGES - You look and respond. Whoever reached out first gets the first chance to pull you closer.
4) THINK IT THROUGH - You sit with the risk and choose your next move carefully. Careful choices build reputation and can starve desire.

S11.text:
You stay after the shift ends.

The hospital changes once the day crowd thins. The noise lowers, but the tension does not. Conversations slow down. People say what they actually think.

In the residents lounge, a male intern flips between channels, half watching a game, half watching the room. He nods when you enter.

"Hell of a shift," he says.

You talk about the case. Then the fight. Then nothing in particular. The conversation loosens.

Eventually, he mentions someone by name. Casual. Offhand. Then with a grin, he adds that they do not do subtle. They like who they like, and they do not pretend otherwise.

"If they are into you," he says, "you will know."

It is not an offer. It is information.

You file it away.

---

CHOICES
1) Express interest - You ask a little more, curious but careful.
2) Joke it off - You laugh and change the subject.
3) Ask details - You press for specifics and reputation.
4) Shut it down - You keep things professional.

S12.text:
You keep your tone light, but you do not hide your curiosity.

The intern notices. He always does.

He tells you enough to matter and not enough to be useful. Who flirts. Who does not. Who talks. Who listens.

He does not warn you. He does not encourage you.

"Just saying," he adds, leaning back. "Some people do not separate work from the rest of their life."

The room hums with the game again.

---

CHOICES
1) Change subject - You steer away before it gets personal.
2) Remember names - You quietly commit the information to memory.
3) Ask risks - You ask what happened to others.
4) End night - You call it and head out.

S13.text:
You laugh it off.

If there is one thing you have learned already, it is that rumors travel faster than test results.

The intern smirks but lets it go. The conversation drifts back to work, to exhaustion, to gallows humor.

You leave without making a move.

It feels safe.

---

CHOICES
1) Leave hospital - You head out for the night.
2) Grab food - You stop by the kitchen first.
3) Stay longer - You linger and listen.
4) Text someone - You check your phone.

S14.text:
You ask for details.

The intern studies you for a moment, deciding how much to say.

"They get what they want," he finally says. "Sometimes they get burned. Sometimes other people do."

That is not a warning. It is a history lesson.

---

CHOICES
1) Ask more - You want names and stories.
2) Thank him - You stop before it goes too far.
3) Play it cool - You pretend it does not matter.
4) Change topic - You redirect the conversation.

S15.text:
You shut it down cleanly.

The intern respects it. Or at least pretends to.

The message is clear. You are here to work. Anything else is noise.

It costs you nothing.

It gains you nothing.

---

CHOICES
1) Leave now - You end the night.
2) Stay focused - You review charts.
3) Get food - You head to the kitchen.
4) Text home - You disconnect.

S16.text:
Time passes.

Conversations overlap. People come and go. You listen more than you speak.

This place runs on patterns. On favors. On who owes who.

You begin to see it.

---

CHOICES
1) Head out - You leave before fatigue wins.
2) Kitchen stop - You grab something to eat.
3) Check phone - Messages pile up.
4) Stay late - You wait and watch.

S17.text:
Your phone buzzes.

Messages from people already home. From people still here. From people watching.

You realize something.

Even when you are not present, the hospital still has opinions about you.

---

CHOICES
1) Respond - You engage.
2) Ignore - You keep distance.
3) Leave now - You shut it all off.
4) Get food - You ground yourself.

S18.text:
The night deepens.

People are tired enough to be honest. Or careless.

You hear things you probably were not meant to.

None of it feels accidental.

---

CHOICES
1) Act now - You make a move.
2) File it away - You remember everything.
3) Leave quietly - You avoid being seen.
4) Get food - You break away.

S19.text:
You leave the hospital.

The doors slide shut behind you. The noise fades.

Tomorrow will remember what you did today.

Whether you want it to or not.

---

CHOICES
1) Go home - You reset.
2) Stay out - You avoid sleep.
3) Reflect - You think it through.
4) Check phone - You reconnect.

S20.text:
The kitchen is quiet.

Night staff move slower. Speak lower.

Someone recognizes you and nods.

Then they ask for something.

Not a lot.

Just enough to matter.

---

CHOICES
1) Agree now - You help without hesitation.
2) Ask details - You want context first.
3) Decline politely - You draw a line.
4) Set terms - You accept with limits.

S21.text:
The hospital changes after hours.

Lights dim in places no one thinks to turn off. Voices drop. The urgency softens into something more personal.

You find yourself lingering instead of leaving. Not because you were asked to, but because something in you wanted to see what happens when the pace slows.

A fellow intern falls into step beside you, talking about the game, the fight, the noise of the city waiting outside these walls.

He mentions someone in passing. Casual. Almost careless.

Someone who never seems to settle.

---

CHOICES
1) Ask about them - You show interest without committing.
2) Joke it off - You keep things light and deflect.
3) Press for details - You want to know more.
4) Change subject - You steer away from gossip.

S22.text:
You ask casually, like it does not matter.

The intern smirks. He notices everything.

He tells you just enough to paint a picture. Availability. Reputation. Choices made loudly and without apology.

It sounds tempting. It also sounds messy.

---

CHOICES
1) Express interest - You admit curiosity.
2) Downplay it - You pretend it means nothing.
3) Ask where to find them - You lean in.
4) Shift focus - You pull back.

S23.text:
You joke. Deflect. Keep it moving.

The intern laughs and drops it.

But the idea stays.

Later, hunger creeps in. The cafeteria is quieter now, mostly staff finishing long shifts.

A familiar face behind the counter nods when they see you.

---

CHOICES
1) Grab food - You stop before heading out.
2) Skip it - You decide to leave now.
3) Make conversation - You linger.
4) Observe quietly - You stay unnoticed.

S24.text:
You ask questions.

The intern studies you, then answers. Not just about them, but about how this place works after dark.

Who helps who. Who owes favors. Who pretends they do not.

By the time the conversation ends, you realize something important.

Opportunities here do not announce themselves.

---

CHOICES
1) Seek it out - You decide to follow a lead.
2) Stay cautious - You do not chase it.
3) Ask for intro - You want a connection.
4) Walk away - You disengage.

S25.text:
You leave the hospital behind.

At home, the silence feels heavier than expected.

Your phone buzzes. Messages trickle in. Snippets of what you missed.

Someone stayed late. Someone crossed a line. Someone noticed.

You are not removed from it.

You are just choosing how close you want to be.

---

CHOICES
1) Respond - You engage from a distance.
2) Ignore it - You keep your space.
3) Ask questions - You want clarity.
4) Go back - You change your mind.

S26.text:
You find yourself in a quiet corner of the hospital.

Someone you have seen before approaches you differently now. Less formal. More direct.

They ask for something small.

Nothing official.

Nothing dangerous.

Just help.

The way they ask tells you this is not about the task.

It is about what kind of person you are going to be.

---

CHOICES
1) Agree quickly - You help without hesitation.
2) Ask questions - You want details first.
3) Decline politely - You refuse cleanly.
4) Set conditions - You agree on your terms.

S27.text:
You say yes without pausing.

The favor is small. Mundane. Something that would never make a report.

You do it quickly and keep your head down. The staff member thanks you like this was expected, like you were always going to help.

As you finish, you notice movement nearby. A shadow passing the doorway. Someone glancing in and then moving on.

Probably nothing.

Still, the feeling sticks.

You did not break a rule. But you did cross a line.

---

CHOICES
1) Leave quickly - You step out before anyone can ask questions.
2) Ask who knows - You quietly ask if anyone else saw.
3) Stay nearby - You linger to read the room.
4) Downplay it - You tell yourself it meant nothing.

S28.text:
You ask questions before agreeing.

The staff member hesitates, then explains. Not everything. Just enough.

It is not urgent. It is not dangerous. It does help them more than it helps anyone else.

They watch your reaction closely.

This is the moment where trust forms or dissolves.

---

CHOICES
1) Do it anyway - You help, knowing exactly what it means.
2) Decline now - You step back after hearing the details.
3) Offer alternative - You suggest a cleaner solution.
4) Ask for time - You delay the decision.

S29.text:
You decline, calmly and without judgment.

The staff member nods and accepts it. Too smoothly.

The conversation ends. The moment passes.

Nothing bad happens.

Nothing good happens either.

You leave knowing you drew a line. You just do not know yet what it cost you.

---

CHOICES
1) Leave kitchen - You walk away clean.
2) Reconsider - You stop yourself before exiting.
3) Make small talk - You soften the refusal.
4) Reflect alone - You sit with the choice.

S30.text:
You agree, but only with conditions.

The staff member pauses. Then nods.

Nothing is written down. Nothing is promised. But something has changed.

This is not a favor anymore. It is an exchange.

You both know it.

---

CHOICES
1) Follow through - You complete the favor carefully.
2) Ask return - You state what you want back.
3) Delay action - You wait before acting.
4) Back out - You decide against it.

S31.text:
You step away from the moment before it can harden into something permanent.

The hospital does not protest. It rarely does. It simply absorbs decisions and remembers them.

As you move down the hallway, you catch fragments of conversations. Someone is being paged. Someone is being warned. Someone is laughing too loudly for how tired they look.

You realize that tonight did not hinge on one choice.

It hinged on how visible you made yourself while making it.

You feel eyes on you that you cannot locate.

Not judgment.

Assessment.

----------------
CHOICES
1) SEEK DISTRACTION - You find something else to focus on and let the tension dissipate.
2) CHECK IN - You look for someone familiar and ground yourself.
3) HEAD HOME - You leave before the night writes more into you.
4) STAY ALERT - You remain present and watch what unfolds.

S32.text:
You keep moving.

Not aimless. Just uncommitted.

In a place like this, that is a choice in itself.

You pass through spaces meant for rest that never quite allow it. Chairs angled wrong. Coffee burned hours ago. A television muttering to no one.

You overhear a name you recognize.

Then another.

You start to see how stories form here. Not from facts. From proximity.

Someone will connect tonight to tomorrow.

You decide whether that someone is you.

----------------
CHOICES
1) INSERT YOURSELF - You step into the conversation and make yourself known.
2) LISTEN ONLY - You stay silent and learn.
3) MOVE ON - You choose not to be part of this story.
4) MESSAGE SOMEONE - You reach out before someone reaches you.

S33.text:
You find someone you trust enough to stand near.

The conversation is normal on the surface. Complaints. Jokes. Fatigue worn like armor.

Underneath it, you sense calculation.

They ask how your shift went.

Not what you did.

How it went.

You realize that your answer will travel.

----------------
CHOICES
1) BE HONEST - You speak plainly and let the truth land where it may.
2) BE STRATEGIC - You shape the story before it spreads.
3) DEFLECT - You keep it vague and noncommittal.
4) TURN QUESTION - You redirect and learn instead.

S34.text:
You leave.

Not dramatically. Not hurried.

Just enough to make it clear you chose distance.

Outside, the night feels wider than the hospital ever did. The city hums without urgency. No alarms. No eyes measuring your worth.

Your phone stays quiet longer than you expect.

Then it buzzes.

One message.

No context.

Just enough to pull you back if you let it.

----------------
CHOICES
1) RESPOND - You open the door again.
2) IGNORE - You keep the night to yourself.
3) SAVE IT - You do not answer now, but you do not delete it.
4) TURN BACK - You change your mind and return.

S36.text:
You decide not to pretend this was an accident.

If you are on the map now, then you may as well read it.

You stop minimizing what happened. You stop treating the favor like a fluke. You pay attention to who suddenly makes time for you and who no longer does. You notice how certain requests come your way quietly, always framed as optional, always paired with an expectation.

You do not chase them.

You let them come to you.

It works.

Your name circulates. Not loudly. Not formally. But enough. You get looped into conversations you used to overhear from the hall. You are asked opinions instead of given instructions. Nothing illegal. Nothing explicit. Just influence.

The resident starts trusting you with cases that matter. The nurse watches you carefully now, like she is deciding whether you are dangerous or useful or both.

Your rival notices the shift. He does not comment. That makes it worse.

This path is efficient.

It is also slippery.

Every time you say yes, it gets easier to say it again.

----------------
CHOICES
1) DOUBLE DOWN - You continue leveraging the momentum and accept bigger asks. This accelerates status but compounds risk and moral erosion.
2) CONTROL DAMAGE - You slow the pace and start choosing only favors that cannot burn you later. You keep power while limiting exposure.
3) LOOP SOMEONE IN - You quietly bring one person into your confidence to stabilize the situation. Shared knowledge can protect or destroy you.
4) STEP BACK - You deliberately reduce visibility before things escalate further. You lose momentum but regain control.

S37.text:
You draw the line.

Not dramatically. Not publicly.

You become precise.

You stop doing favors that feel vague. You ask questions that make people uncomfortable. You document more carefully. You keep your tone neutral and your actions boring.

Some people respect it immediately.

Others react like you broke an unspoken agreement.

You feel the shift in small ways. Fewer side conversations. Fewer casual invitations. A faint cooling in the air when you enter certain rooms.

But there is something else too.

Trust.

The kind that does not ask for shortcuts. The kind that comes with heavier responsibility instead of quieter leverage.

The resident gives you a look one afternoon that says she knows exactly what you are doing. She does not comment.

The nurse seems relieved. Or disappointed. You cannot tell which.

This path is slower.

It is cleaner.

----------------
CHOICES
1) HOLD THE LINE - You maintain strict boundaries and let consequences fall where they may. You protect integrity at the cost of influence.
2) EXPLAIN YOURSELF - You clarify your stance to someone important. You risk misunderstanding but may preserve key relationships.
3) REASSERT VALUE - You prove your worth through excellence instead of favors. It takes time but builds durable respect.
4) RECONSIDER - You question whether this rigidity is costing you too much and consider easing up.

S38.text:
You choose an ally.

Not out of panic. Out of calculation.

You pick someone you believe understands the difference between confidence and confession. You do not spill everything. You tell just enough to test the ground.

Their reaction matters more than their words.

They listen.

They ask the right questions.

They do not rush to judge.

You feel the weight shift off your chest slightly. Shared knowledge changes the geometry of risk. You are no longer the only one holding the shape of the truth.

But trust is never neutral.

Who you tell defines who you are becoming.

If this goes wrong, it will not be because you were careless.

It will be because you chose.

----------------
CHOICES
1) FULL DISCLOSURE - You tell them everything and accept the consequences. You gain deep trust or catastrophic exposure.
2) PARTIAL TRUTH - You keep details vague and protect yourself. You gain limited support and preserve deniability.
3) ASK ADVICE - You step back and let them guide your next move. You surrender some control for perspective.
4) PULL BACK - You regret opening up and reduce contact. You contain risk but damage the bond.

S39.text:
You withdraw.

Not abruptly. Not obviously.

You become harder to reach.

You stop lingering. You leave on time. You decline invitations with polite excuses that sound reasonable and feel hollow.

At first, nothing happens.

Then things adjust.

Opportunities stop presenting themselves. Conversations close before you enter them. People assume you are not interested and move on without you.

You sleep better.

You also feel smaller.

Safety has a cost, and it is not always visible on paper.

You are still competent. Still respected.

But you are no longer shaping anything.

----------------
CHOICES
1) STAY WITHDRAWN - You commit to distance and prioritize stability. You avoid risk and accept stagnation.
2) RE-ENGAGE SLOWLY - You return selectively and test the waters. You risk reopening old doors carefully.
3) CHANGE TRACK - You look for fulfillment outside hospital politics. You redefine success on your terms.
4) REVERSE COURSE - You decide withdrawal was a mistake and step back into the current fully.
